author: By Katrin Bennhold, Ana Swanson, Rikki Novetsky, Mooj Zadie, Eric Krupke, Luke Vander Ploeg, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: The Battle to Control the World’s Most Powerful Technology
description: Nvidia chips, which are crucial to artificial intelligence, are traded actively in China, despite U.S. restrictions, The Times found.
content: The American company Nvidia has created one of the world’s most sought-after inventions: a computer chip that powers artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Bucket List
description: What items did you cross off your list of summer pleasures this year?
content: What makes summer feel like summer to you? How many of those things did you get to do this year?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Pope Praises Indonesia’s ‘Delicate Balance’ of Unity in Diversity
description: Speaking in Jakarta, the pontiff said “mutual respect” was the key to harmony in the majority-Muslim country, where a pluralist tradition has been put to the test by extremist groups.
content: Pope Francis on Wednesday praised Indonesia’s founding principles of unity in diversity in his first public address in the country but also stressed vigilance against intolerance and extremism.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Extreme Weather Is Increasing Risk of Collapse for U.S. Bridges
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 4, 2024.
content: “It’s getting so hot that the pieces that hold the concrete and steel, those bridges can literally fall apart like Tinkertoys.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Mother and Daughter Endure Lockdowns in Separate Schools After Georgia Shooting
description: Anetra Pattman was teaching class when her daughter texted: “Mom, I heard gunshots. I’m scared. Please come get me.”
content: Anetra Pattman, 43, was teaching social sciences at the alternative school in Barrow County, Ga., when she received a text on Wednesday at 10:24 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Phoenix Marks 100 Straight Days of 100-Degree Temperatures
description: The city reached the sweaty milestone on Tuesday. The previous record of 76 straight days was set in 1993.
content: For Phoenix, a city accustomed to intense heat, the dog days of summer have been exceptional this year. On Tuesday, the city reached a milestone, marking its 100th straight day with temperatures of at least 100 degrees Fahrenheit, meteorologists said, adding there was no end in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman, Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
title: With Hopes Frayed in Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, Mediators Plan a New Push
description: The latest proposals to bridge the remaining gaps between Israel and Hamas have yet to be finalized. Both Israel and Hamas have expressed pessimism over the prospects for an agreement.
content: International mediators are finalizing a new cease-fire proposal to narrow the gaps between Israel and Hamas, U.S. and regional officials said, even as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu insists he will not give up control of Gaza’s border with Egypt — a key stumbling point for a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 452
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Sept. 5, 2024.
content: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level, and whether you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Jim Riswold, Creator of ‘Bo Knows’ and Air Jordan Ads, Dies at 66
description: His work for Nike — particularly commercials starring Michael Jordan and Spike Lee — blurred the line between advertising and entertainment.
content: Jim Riswold, a visionary and irreverent adman whose playful and occasionally provocative Nike commercials featuring Michael Jordan, Tiger Woods and Bo Jackson redrew the playing field for product endorsements and propelled athletic footwear into the cultural stratosphere, died on Aug. 9 at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amrit Singh and Adriana Garcia
title: Electing Judges in Mexico? It’s a Bad Idea.
description: The judicial overhaul in Mexico could harm government accountability, undermine the justice system and give even greater power to drug cartels.
content: For weeks, Mexico has been in turmoil over President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s proposed constitutional amendment for judges to be elected by popular vote. Fifty-five thousand judicial employees went on strike as legislators pushed the law forward; the peso fell, and international banks issued dire warnings about the effect of the proposal on the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Tan
title: Internet Archive Loses Court Appeal in Fight Over Online Lending Library
description: The dispute started in the early days of the pandemic when the organization expanded access to a free online collection of books.
content: When libraries across the country temporarily closed in the early days of the pandemic, the Internet Archive, an organization that digitizes and archives materials like web pages and music, had the idea to make its library of scanned books free to read in an online database.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Linda Deutsch, The A.P.’s Dean of Courtroom Reporting, Dies at 80
description: Covering notorious trials, she offered readers an unvarnished view of the sordid side of celebrity, told through many of the country’s most riveting legal dramas.
content: Linda Deutsch, who covered high-profile trials in nearly 50 years as a reporter with The Associated Press, starting with the one surrounding the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy and including the defendants O.J. Simpson, Michael Jackson and Charles Manson, died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Qasim Nauman
title: Missile and Drone Attacks Across Ukraine Kill at Least 7 in Lviv
description: Russia attacked a number of cities a day after a devastating strike in the country’s east, Ukrainian officials said.
content: Russia bombarded a swath of Ukraine early Wednesday, killing at least seven people in the western city of Lviv, local Ukrainian officials said, a day after a ballistic missile attack in the eastern city of Poltava left dozens of people dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Some Navels
description: Kareem Ayas waxes poetic.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: A Democracy With Everything but a Choice
description: A new analysis of American elections finds that in half of all races for partisan offices, a candidate runs unopposed. Democrats are the biggest no-shows.
content: This November, voters in rural Perry County, Mo., will face a ballot with candidates for a bevy of local offices: state senator, state representative and circuit judge; two county commissioners, sheriff and many more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Republican Subpoenas Blinken Over Afghanistan Withdrawal
description: The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee summoned the secretary of state for testimony just days before an expected report on the U.S. exit, in which 13 American service members were killed.
content: The Republican chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Tuesday issued a subpoena for Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s testimony, threatening to hold him in contempt if he failed to address the panel later this month about the chaotic U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: How the Presidential Election Got This Close
description: Polarization doesn’t just pull us apart; it holds coalitions together.
content: As Donald Trump turns to obscenity, racial disparagement and sexual innuendo to blunt Kamala Harris’s surge in the polls, he faces a daunting obstacle: the intense hostility among Democrats to all things Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Brockovich, Alison Bruzek and Derek Arthur
title: These Chemicals Are Hurting Us. Why Aren’t We Regulating Them?
description: Erin Brockovich is sounding the alarm on forever chemicals.
content: They’ve been found in our milk, our eggs, our water supply and our bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Tim Sheehy Was Recorded Using Racist Stereotypes About Native Americans
description: Mr. Sheehy, a Republican, is the nominee for a Senate seat in Montana, where Indigenous residents make up about 6 percent of the population.
content: Tim Sheehy, the Republican nominee for U.S. Senate in Montana, made comments perpetuating racist stereotypes about Native Americans during private fund-raisers last year, according to recordings of the events published by a local news outlet late last week and obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Biden’s Asylum Restrictions Were Meant to Be Temporary. That Could Change.
description: The Biden administration is considering actions that would make the tough restrictions the president ordered in June almost impossible to lift.
content: The Biden administration is considering actions that would make President Biden’s tough but temporary asylum restrictions almost impossible to lift, people familiar with the plans said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samanta Schweblin and Translated by Megan McDowell
title: Read Your Way Through Buenos Aires
description: Buenos Aires is a literary city: Its residents like to boast about its many bookstores and independent publishers. Samanta Schweblin suggests which books and authors to start with.
content: When I started traveling, I came to realize just how different Buenos Aires was from other literary cities. Maybe we all have similar thoughts about our hometowns, or maybe my revelation is just one more confirmation of the arrogance for which we porteños — people raised in the port city of Buenos Aires — are famous throughout the rest of Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Elton John Says a Serious Eye Infection Limited His Vision in One Eye
description: The entertainer said on social media that it would “take some time” before sight returned to his eye.
content: Elton John said he was recuperating from a severe eye infection that limited his vision in one eye, but that he was optimistic about his recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Expands Its ‘How to Vote’ Resources Ahead of the Election
description: The company is an increasingly popular source of political news. It’s adding more content about how elections work and media literacy.
content: TikTok is pushing to improve information about the upcoming U.S. presidential election on the app, it said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Hall
title: It’s Party Time on the Stockholm-Helsinki Ferry
description: The 16-hour trip between the two northern European cities is a festive summer ritual, with plenty of singing, gambling, limbo contests and maybe a bit too much to drink.
content: The party started an hour before the M/S Gabriella ferry slipped out of Stockholm harbor for its overnight voyage to Helsinki. At the outdoor bar on Deck 9, passengers had gathered for the 4 p.m. sailing. Talking excitedly over drinks, they reveled in the Nordic summer weather — bright sun, cool breeze, electric blue sky with cotton-ball clouds — while a D.J. mixed bass-heavy Eurodance and vintage disco. Kids on holiday with their families dashed about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris and Trump Campaigns Agree to Debate’s Microphone Rules
description: The microphones at the candidates’ debate next Tuesday will be muted when it’s not their turn to speak.
content: The great debate microphone muting drama of 2024 has come to a quiet end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: Appointments Are a Simple Way to Deepen Your Friendships. Trust Me.
description: A standing meeting at the diner has led to new levels in connection and community.
content: Every Sunday morning, I walk to my local diner and order a stack of three pancakes, a bowl of fruit, two scrambled eggs and a black coffee. Two friends almost always meet me there. Ty — whom I first got to know in San Francisco, where we both volunteered at a music-events company — gets the corned-beef hash with melted cheese on top. David, whom I met through Ty, drifts from eggs benedict to a breakfast burrito to the occasional chopped cheese. What’s for breakfast doesn’t really matter much, though. That we meet — at the same time and place — does. Recently, we marked almost 40 Sundays running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alessandro Marazzi Sassoon, Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
title: As Gunfire Rang Out, Students and Teachers Huddled in Fear
description: In classrooms, screams and voices urging everyone to stay quiet were heard. Some had to stay put for more than an hour.
content: The lockdown alert flashed on a screen in Stephen Kreyenbuhl’s classroom at Apalachee High School as the gunfire started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Ukraine’s Top Diplomat Has Become a Familiar Face, Rallying Wartime Support
description: Dmytro Kuleba has lobbied Kyiv’s allies to supply missile defense systems. He was among several Ukrainian ministers who offered to resign on Wednesday, an official said.
content: When Russian forces rolled across the border into Ukraine at the start of their full-scale invasion in February 2022, Dmytro Kuleba, Ukraine’s foreign minister, compared the assault to Nazi Germany’s in World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Families of Patients Who Died Sue Hospital After Fentanyl Was Swapped With Water
description: The tap water was placed in the intravenous drips of patients at a hospital in Medford, Ore., causing bacterial infections.
content: The families of 18 patients who contracted bacterial infections have sued a southern Oregon hospital, accusing it of failing it to prevent a nurse from replacing fentanyl in intravenous drips with tap water that caused the infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: How Trump Wins (and Harris and the Democrats Blow It)
description: The former president’s campaign comes down to the “five turbines of Trumpism.”
content: It’s Nov. 6, 2024, the morning after Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: Texas Attorney General Sues to Stop Voter Registration Push in San Antonio
description: The suit is the newest front in an escalating conflict over elections between the Republicans who dominate state government and the Democrats who control the state’s major cities.
content: Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas went to court on Wednesday to try to stop county leaders in San Antonio from sending out more than 200,000 voter registration applications to unregistered residents of Bexar County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: The Hurricane Season Was Supposed to Be Busy. What Happened?
description: An intermission in hurricanes across the Atlantic has people wondering where the predicted storms are.
content: Halfway through an Atlantic hurricane season that forecasters expected would be one of the most active on record, there has been a considerable interlude in storms during what is typically the busiest portion of the season, leaving observers to wonder if the forecast was a bust — or if the worst may be yet to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Venezuelan and Proxy Forces Linked to at Least 6 Protester Deaths, Rights Group Says
description: The Human Rights Watch report marks the first effort by a major international organization to verify some of the two-dozen reported deaths in protests since Venezuela’s disputed presidential election.
content: Venezuelan security forces and armed groups aligned with the government committed widespread violence against protesters and killed some of them following the country’s disputed presidential election, according to a report on Wednesday by Human Rights Watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Tan
title: Waymo’s Robot Taxis Are Almost Mainstream. Can They Now Turn a Profit?
description: Now that its technology is showing it can work on city streets, Alphabet, which owns Waymo, plans to invest billions more.
content: Over the last few months, Waymo’s robot taxis have become an unmistakable part of the San Francisco experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Inside the Pope’s Visit to Indonesia
description: Starting in the majority-Muslim nation, Francis is undertaking a multiday journey through Asia and Oceania.
content: Pope Francis began his 11-day tour of four island nations across Southeast Asia and Oceania on Tuesday, an ambitious endeavor that will bring him to faraway corners of the Roman Catholic world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jesse McKinley and William K. Rashbaum
title: In Deciding When to Sentence Trump, Judge Faces ‘Impossible’ Task
description: Justice Juan M. Merchan has tried to treat Donald J. Trump like the hundreds of other defendants whose fates he has decided. But his decision could alter American history.
content: As Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial wrapped up in May, one of his lawyers wanted to give the jury unusual instructions that would have made it harder to convict him. A special case warranted special rules, the lawyer argued, and the first prosecution of a former American president was “obviously an extraordinarily important case.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli and Sinna Nasseri
title: Mk.gee, an Unlikely Guitar God, Chases the Promise of Pop
description: At 27, he has a desire to rethink how music is made, and the confidence to do it. Stars including Eric Clapton, Frank Ocean and Justin Bieber are buying in.
content: On first listen, or even fourth, the songs of Michael Gordon, a guitarist, producer and vocalist who performs as Mk.gee, are not the sort one imagines generating a modern frenzy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Thomas
title: Luca Guadagnino Gets Crafty
description: The film director and designer did double duty in Venice, Italy, debuting a film at the Venice Film Festival along with his curation of Homo Faber, the craftsmanship exhibition.
content: Luca Guadagnino has added creative director to his list of jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Andrew Duehren and Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris Tells the Business Community: I’m Friendlier Than Biden
description: The vice president on Wednesday proposed an increase on the capital gains tax that was far less than what President Biden has floated, one of several moves meant to win over business owners.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris on Wednesday sought to put daylight between herself and President Biden on tax policy, making it the first issue on which she is trying to stand apart from an administration in which she holds a key role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It OK to Vote for My Third-Party Fave This Presidential Election?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the efficacy of voting your conscience.
content: I’m caught in a bind between two parties, the Democratic Party and the Green Party. I believe in the message and values of the Green Party candidate; however, they never seem to get elected, so many suggest voting for them is moot. This feels like a catch-22. But with the upcoming presidential election, my peers suggest that voting for a third party ensures a Republican victory, akin to supporting the opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,174
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, September 5, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: We Have Reached the Scrounging-for-Scandals Phase of the Campaign
description: The false “stolen valor” claim isn’t sticking, but that hasn’t stopped conservatives from using it.
content: On Sunday, Dustin Grage, a columnist for the conservative website Townhall and a Republican strategist who describes himself as a “Minnesota G.O.P. hype man,” posted on X a clip from a 2012 speech by Tim Walz to the American Legion. In the clip, Walz says: “When I was in Afghanistan, you know what our troops were worried about? They were worried about their family’s health care, and they were worried about their pensions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Climate Change Is Making ‘Last Chance Tourism’ More Popular, and Riskier
description: More tourists are eager to visit vanishing glaciers and ice caves, but warming is also making the sites unstable.
content: An American tourist was visiting an ice cave in one of Europe’s largest national parks last month when a frozen arch collapsed, killing him and injuring his girlfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Jordyn Holman
title: Nordstrom Family Offers $3.8 Billion to Buy Its Namesake Retailer
description: The $23-per-share offer by the department store’s founding family comes as retailers struggle to navigate new shopping trends and costly real estate.
content: The family behind Nordstrom, one of the country’s oldest department stores, is offering to take it private for $3.8 billion, the company announced in a regulatory filing on Wednesday, as retailers struggle to navigate new shopping trends and their costly store bases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Do You Get the ‘September Scaries’?
description: How are you feeling as summer ends and a new school year begins?
content: It’s September and, for many, that means back to school — back to responsibilities, a regular schedule and waking up early. Do you look forward to this time of year? Or does it make you stressed and anxious?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Liz Cheney, a Top G.O.P. Trump Critic, Says She Will Vote for Harris
description: The Wyoming Republican, once a member of House leadership, lost her post and then her seat after she voted to impeach President Donald J. Trump following the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
content: Former Representative Liz Cheney, the once high-ranking Republican from Wyoming who torpedoed her political career by breaking forcefully with former President Donald J. Trump, said on Wednesday she would be voting for Vice President Kamala Harris in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Murphy
title: Sitting All Day Can Cause Dead Butt Syndrome
description: The name might make you snicker, but addressing “gluteal amnesia” can help you avoid chronic pain.
content: After a long workday at your desk or hours in a car, it’s normal to feel a little stiff. It may just be that your hip flexors and lower back are tight. But you could also be experiencing a potentially debilitating condition called gluteal amnesia, or dead butt syndrome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Trudeau’s Hold on Power Slips After Collapse of Governing Agreement
description: A left-leaning party that helped Canada’s Liberals build a majority in Parliament announced it was ending its support, making it possible an election is called early.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada may be forced into an election earlier than expected after a left-leaning political party that had been propping up his government in Parliament announced on Wednesday that it was abandoning the arrangement.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 4, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 4, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about the president of Mexico’s plan for transforming the judiciary misstated which judges could be fired or impeached under a planned Tribunal for Judicial Discipline. Supreme Court justices could not be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Two Florida Moms, One Congressional Seat and the Future of MAGA
description: Representative Anna Paulina Luna, a Trump acolyte, is vulnerable to her challenger, Whitney Fox, in Florida’s 13th District.
content: On a steamy weekend in June, I went to St. Petersburg to report on the race for Congress in Florida’s 13th Congressional District. In a heavily gerrymandered and polarized country, it’s one of the few congressional races that the nonpartisan Cook Political Report highlighted as even vaguely competitive. They described the race as “likely Republican,” as Republicans typically receive six more points of the vote share than Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: A Perfect Match for a Sexy Brand?
description: Haider Ackermann, a coolly sensual designer, is the new creative director at Tom Ford.
content: Tom Ford, a brand long associated with the sexy, glamorous aesthetic of its eponymous founder, has a new creative director: Haider Ackermann, a designer known for his superb tailoring skills and mastery of varied materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: With New Taliban Manifesto, Afghan Women Fear the Worst
description: Three years into its rule, the movement has codified its harsh Islamic decrees into law that now includes a ban on women’s voices in public.
content: No education beyond the sixth grade. No employment in most workplaces and no access to public spaces like parks, gyms and salons. No long-distance travel if unaccompanied by a male relative. No leaving home if not covered from head to toe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Pedro Almodóvar, Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton on ‘The Room Next Door’
description: The director’s first English-language feature inspires talk of beauty, hope and more collaborations.
content: At Monday night’s Venice after-party for “The Room Next Door,” Pedro Almodóvar beamed at his leading ladies as they beamed back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Desperate Bid to Save J.F.K. Shown in Resurfaced Film
description: The footage from 1963, taken by a Texas businessman and seen only by a few, shows the president’s limousine speeding to a Dallas hospital. It is being auctioned this month.
content: Nearly 61 years ago, Dale Carpenter Sr. showed up on Lemmon Avenue in Dallas, hoping to film John F. Kennedy as his motorcade passed. But the president’s car had already gone by, and he recorded only some of the procession, including the back of a car carrying Lyndon Johnson and the side of the White House press bus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia Imprisons Top Physicists, Even as Putin Touts Their Technology
description: A Moscow court sentenced Alexander Shiplyuk, the director of a physics institute who specializes in hypersonic flight, to 15 years in prison. It was the latest treason case against a leading scientist.
content: Russian scientists helped make their country a leader in developing cutting-edge missiles that fly at least five times as fast as the speed of sound. Then Russia started calling them traitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Shea and Hisato Tasaka
title: Oversize Coats Are the Season’s Biggest Trend
description: Giant, tailored wool outerwear is a cozy yet polished choice this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Webster Ayuso
title: 6 European Cities Where You Can Swim in the Wild
description: Looking to take a dip in or near a city center? Here are some urban areas that have successfully opened up waterways for swimmers.
content: The Olympic Games in Paris generated a lot of excitement around the cleanup project of the Seine River, where triathlon and swimming competitions took place. And there’s more to come: Mayor Anne Hidalgo plans to open three public swimming spots on the Seine by next summer, and similar projects are in the works in Boston, London and Amsterdam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: J. Richard Munro, Who Oversaw the Creation of Time Warner, Dies at 93
description: As president and C.E.O., he expanded Time Inc.’s offerings, fended off a hostile takeover and built the world’s largest media company.
content: J. Richard Munro, who as chairman and chief executive of Time Inc. navigated the company from its home in magazine publishing through the stormy media seas of the 1980s and, ultimately, to its momentous purchase of Warner Communications in 1989, creating the world’s largest media corporation, died on Aug. 11 in Naples, Fla. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye and River Akira Davis
title: Wall Street Is Unsettled Again, After Fueling a Global Sell-Off
description: Another day of anxiety hit stock markets around the world, with technology stocks the focus of attention.
content: Markets remained unsettled on Wednesday as technology stocks continued to fall, dragging down stock indexes across the world for a second consecutive day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Four People Were Killed in a School Shooting in Georgia
description: Also, Zelensky is preparing to shake up his cabinet. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: A 14-year-old student opened fire today in the hallway of a Georgia high school, killing two students and two teachers and injuring at least nine others, the authorities said. The shooting — the deadliest episode of school violence in Georgia’s history — took place at Apalachee High School in Winder, roughly 50 miles from the center of Atlanta. Here’s the latest on what we know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $925,000 Homes in New York, Virginia and Missouri
description: A saltbox-style house in Ancram, a Tudor Revival cottage in Richmond and a four-bedroom home in St. Louis.
content: This property is on a picturesque country road and has a series of terraced gardens, some devoted to wildflowers, and a swimming pool with sweeping views of the Berkshires. The town has a wine shop and a small general store and coffee shop, about five minutes away by car. Copake Lake is about 15 minutes away. Mount Washington State Forest is 20 minutes away, across the Massachusetts border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Watching Movies Like It’s 1999
description: A multimedia Culture desk series, “Class of 1999,” revisits a group of mold-breaking, star-studded films released that year.
content: A sci-fi film whose climactic choice — red pill or blue pill? — has become so famous that it’s a meme. A found-footage style documentary horror film that achieved cult-classic status. A “Star Wars,” a “Toy Story” and two Tom Cruise movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jyoti Madhusoodanan
title: Can I Lower My Cholesterol Without Taking a Statin?
description: Here’s what the evidence suggests can work.
content: Q: I have high cholesterol, but when I tried statins, I didn’t like the side effects. What are non-pharmaceutical ways to lower my cholesterol?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Shbair, Hiba Yazbek and Abu Bakr Bashir
title: Gazans Grapple With Prospect of Israeli Presence Postwar
description: Some say they will reluctantly stomach a postwar Israeli military presence in the territory if that allows them to go home. Others worry about another long-term occupation.
content: Cease-fire talks in Gaza have stalled again, in part over Israel’s demand to retain a military presence in the territory, which Hamas and Egypt oppose. But the view among some Gazans on that point is less clear-cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘Path to Disaster’: 4 Takeaways From the U.K. Grenfell Fire Final Report
description: An extensive public inquiry found that the causes of the Grenfell Tower tragedy stretched back decades, and that the deaths of 72 people were avoidable.
content: More than seven years after 72 people were killed and dozens more injured when a devastating fire tore through Grenfell Tower, an official inquiry on Wednesday blamed “decades of failures” by the government, dishonesty by companies and a flawed response from London’s fire service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Bannister
title: Seashell Art Is Shedding Its Kitschy Reputation
description: No longer confined to beachy souvenir shops, works encrusted with oysters and mussels are showing up in galleries and interiors.
content: Few symbols of death enchant like seashells, the calcified exoskeletons of mollusks, washed ashore after their tenants’ demise. Often lustrous and intricately patterned, shells have served as passports, currency, navigation aids, jewelry and decoration. In Renaissance Italy, for instance, they were used to adorn artificial grottos built on the grounds of prominent villas, including those of the Medicis. These heavily adorned faux caves — often outfitted with hidden water spouts, stalactites, glass gems and sculptures of mermaids and other mythical sea dwellers — provided refuge from summer heat and counterpoints to the formal gardens that surrounded them. Later, in Victorian Britain, shell mania boomed among the general public as the empire expanded into tropical regions. Women integrated their collections into handicrafts, affixing them to picture frames and boxes and creating shell bouquets. In the time since, shells have remained on the fringes of contemporary art and décor, largely deemed kitsch and relegated to coastal souvenir shops. But now — amid renewed appreciation for organic media in art-making and a climate crisis that renders ocean life ever more precious — artists are once again embracing the shell as both a raw material and muse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Could a Cup Count Predict the Election Result?
description: A shop in the Hamptons sells presidential campaign cups. The top seller usually also wins the race.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at a shop that is once again selling presidential campaign cups and keeping track of the sales numbers. It has done this since 2004, and its final count has been wrong only once — in 2016. We’ll also get details on a former aide to Gov. Kathy Hochul who is accused of acting as a Chinese agent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Takes Stock of Harris Leading in the Polls
description: Colbert reacted to a survey showing the vice president ahead of Donald Trump, 48 percent to 43 percent, saying it “really restores my faith in almost half of humanity.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump Media Shares Are Down 74% From Their March Peak
description: The stock price of the former president’s social media company has often moved in tandem with investor perception of his standing in the presidential race.
content: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company have fallen so much that his onetime $6 billion stake is now worth about $2 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Anna Sorokin Goes From High-Society Impersonator to ‘Dancing With the Stars’
description: The woman who impersonated a German heiress will reprise her false identity on season 33 of the show, becoming the latest contestant with legal or other troubles.
content: It’s a familiar lineup for this season’s “Dancing With the Stars.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caren Lissner
title: A Ruling, Finally, on the Fate of the Palisades in Union City, N.J.
description: After being tied up in litigation for years, an assemblage of 13 properties on the cliffs west of Hoboken will see what the market has in store for them.
content: It’s rare for a sizable parcel of land to come up for sale in Union City, N.J., the third most densely populated city in America, according to the census.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Donovan
title: The Biggest Lie About Baking
description: There’s actually room to have fun, and this stunning, simple clafoutis recipe is one to play with.
content: Clafoutis, the rustic, eggy beauty from France, most certainly stands alone. It’s easy to whip together, delicious whether rewarmed or freshly baked and still gooey or left over for a few days and eaten as cold, firm petits fours with your hot morning coffee. It comforts while exuding an unpretentious elegance. Yet it is not original in technique or ingredients, one of many dishes sharing lineage in the Family of the Delicious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Our Granddaughter’s Boyfriend Is Too Old for Her. What Can We Do?
description: A reader and her husband are united in disapproval of the 14-year age gap in their granddaughter’s relationship. What they don’t agree on is whether to invite him to dinner.
content: My 22-year-old granddaughter is in love with a man who is 36. They have been dating for a year. I want to maintain my closeness with her, so I hide my concern about the age gap. My husband (her grandfather) does not. Recently, our granddaughter told me that she would like to bring her boyfriend to a family dinner, but she is afraid of what her grandfather might say. I’ve tried to ask him to be open about this, but before we get anywhere, he changes the subject. I perceive a commitment looming, and I would like to meet this boyfriend. Our daughter met him, and she likes him. What should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Ms. Taddeo Goes to Hollywood
description: A writer’s success today may be measured in film and television adaptations. Lisa Taddeo, whose book “Three Women” is now a Starz series, hates that.
content: Hollywood couldn’t resist Lisa Taddeo’s book “Three Women” when it was published in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Prosecutor Says Manslaughter Case Against Alec Baldwin Should Be Revived
description: The special prosecutor asked a judge in New Mexico to reconsider her decision to toss the charge against the actor during his trial.
content: A prosecutor who oversaw the involuntary manslaughter case against Alec Baldwin has asked a judge in New Mexico to reconsider her dismissal of the charge during the trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: The Truth About Patti LuPone and Mia Farrow
description: The longtime friends are appearing together in the new Broadway play “The Roommate.” Everything you think you know about them may be wrong.
content: “Sweet and sour?” Patti LuPone suggested, as if considering options on a menu. She looked questioningly at Mia Farrow, who was sitting next to her in a small atelier in a Midtown Manhattan hotel. We were in the heat-soaked throes of early August, and the women had just arrived, depleted, from what they described as an “airless” rehearsal room nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Noel Parmentel Jr., Essayist, Polemicist and Apostate, Dies at 98
description: A self-described “reactionary individualist,” he mentored Joan Didion and was credited with famously comparing Nixon to a used-car salesman.
content: Noel E. Parmentel Jr., a splenetic polemicist and political apostate who mentored Joan Didion, helped persuade Norman Mailer to run for mayor of New York and, as the son of a part-time automobile salesman, was credited with distilling Americans’ doubts about Richard M. Nixon into a single question — “Would you buy a used car from this man?” — died on Saturday in West Haven, Conn. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Winder, a Rural, Middle-Class City in Georgia, Is in a Rapidly Developing Area
description: The site of a school shooting is in a county that has nearly doubled in population since 2000, according to census data.
content: The shooting at Apalachee High School on Wednesday took place in a rural, unincorporated area between the cities of Atlanta and Athens in Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard and Jesus Jiménez
title: The View From the Nosebleeds at the U.S. Open: Not Too Shabby
description: It’s a long way to Row Z. But once you get there, there are advantages, tennis fans say.
content: To reach the last row of Section 323 in Arthur Ashe Stadium — one of the highest vantage points from which to watch U.S. Open matches — is something of a marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Rubsam
title: The First Movie About Pop Music to Nail Its Mediocrity
description: This summer’s “Trap,” from M. Night Shyamalan, works hard to turn its fictional star — and her fans — into heroes.
content: Last fall, I went with friends to see a popular British rock band at Madison Square Garden. I went in a fan of the group, but with every interchangeable song, every self-important gesture, I grew farther apart from the crowd around me: The more they enjoyed the music, the more it bored me. I had been pulled into a conversation with 20,000 other people, but I had nothing to say. By the first set break, I wanted to leave; by the third, I needed to escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Maria Varenikova
title: Ukraine Names Candidates for Its New Cabinet in Major Overhaul
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said that he was acting to bring a “new energy” to state institutions at an important diplomatic juncture.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky pushed ahead with his sweeping overhaul of the senior government ranks as the head of Ukraine’s ruling party released a slate of nine candidates for top cabinet positions Wednesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Andrew E. Kramer, Cade Metz, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: N.Y. Official Accused of Aiding China, and Zelensky Plans Cabinet Shake-Up
description: Plus, robot taxis — with human helpers.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Will North Carolina’s MAGA Extremists Doom Trump?
description: There’s a whiff of Republican panic in this battleground state.
content: Donald Trump was in North Carolina just two weeks ago. And a week before that. And on Friday he’ll be back. Again. It seems he can’t get enough of my state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Police Arrest Man in 1993 Murder of 19-Year-Old Indianapolis Woman
description: For more than 30 years, the case had remained unsolved. While questions remain, the police said they had linked a 52-year-old Missouri man to DNA at the crime scene.
content: More than three decades after Carmen Van Huss was found dead in her Indianapolis apartment, a homicide victim at 19, the police said on Tuesday that they had arrested a suspect, a break in a cold case that had long consumed the Van Huss family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Aftermath of Military Academy Strike Drains Ukraine’s Seasoned Rescuers
description: Repeated air-raid alerts have punctuated the search through the rubble in Poltava, in eastern Ukraine, after an attack that killed more than 50 people.
content: A day after a devastating Russian missile attack that killed more than 50 people in the Ukrainian city of Poltava, bricks splayed out from the stricken military academy building as exhausted rescue workers searched for bodies in the rubble, stopping every so often to listen for cries for help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Hunter Biden’s Legal Woes Return to Spotlight Ahead of Tax Trial
description: As both sides prepare for the start of jury selection on Thursday, there are no indications that any deal is likely, according to several people with knowledge of the situation.
content: Hunter Biden’s trial on tax charges in Los Angeles turned into a political afterthought the moment President Biden withdrew from the 2024 race in July. But the personal stakes for his son, who is staring down the possibility of prison time, have never been higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Republicans Pivot to Attacking Walz With Subpoena Over a Nonprofit’s Fraud
description: The move was the latest sign that House Republicans were moving from investigating and attacking President Biden to taking aim at the new Democratic ticket.
content: A top House Republican on Wednesday issued a subpoena to Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, for details about a years-old fraud scheme in his state in which a nonprofit organization used a pandemic-era program aimed at feeding hungry children to steal $250 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Boeing Starliner Set to Leave Space Station Without Its Crew
description: The troubled spacecraft is scheduled to undock on Friday for a trip back to Earth while two NASA astronauts will stay in orbit.
content: Leaving behind the two NASA astronauts it took to the International Space Station three months ago, Boeing’s troubled Starliner spacecraft is set to begin its return to Earth on Friday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: How Media Outlets on the Left and Right Covered Trump’s Arlington Cemetery Visit
description: Liberal outlets criticized Mr. Trump for turning his visit into a photo opportunity, while conservative ones falsely suggested the altercation never happened.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s visit to Arlington National Cemetery and his campaign’s attempt to film gravesites there last week reignited questions surrounding his politicization of the military. Liberal outlets criticized Mr. Trump for turning his visit into a photo opportunity, while conservative ones falsely suggested that an altercation with a cemetery official hadn’t happened — a line that Mr. Trump echoed on Tuesday, contradicting his campaign’s original account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yuval Noah Harari
title: Yuval Noah Harari: What Happens When the Bots Compete for Your Love?
description: The world will soon be flooded with fake humans.
content: Democracy is a conversation. Its function and survival depend on the available information technology. For most of history, no technology existed for holding large-scale conversations among millions of people. In the premodern world, democracies existed only in small city-states like Rome and Athens, or in even smaller tribes. Once a polity grew large, the democratic conversation collapsed, and authoritarianism remained the only alternative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: 21 Migrants Missing at Sea as Boat Capsizes in Rough Seas Off Italy
description: Seven survivors were rescued from the boat that sank after leaving Libya. A crackdown by Italy has reduced migration, but not the high death rates that come with crossing the Mediterranean.
content: Twenty-one migrants were missing at sea on Wednesday, according to survivors rescued from a sinking boat about 10 miles from the Italian island of Lampedusa, Italy’s Coast Guard said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: A Campus Protest Movement Seeks to Regain Momentum but Faces Hurdles
description: Pro-Palestinian demonstrations appeared at some U.S. campuses, but new restrictions and a new set of students may slow momentum for the type of mass protests seen in the spring.
content: The 50 or so pro-Palestinian demonstrators picketing outside Columbia University’s main gates on the first day of the semester urged students to boycott classes and handed out fliers accusing Columbia of being complicit in genocide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Maggie Haberman
title: Harris and Biden Will Visit World Trade Center Site on Sept. 11, as Trump Mulls the Same
description: This year, the anniversary of the 2001 attacks will come just hours after a presidential debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris and President Biden are set to visit the World Trade Center site in New York City on Sept. 11 to memorialize the 2001 terrorist attacks, while former President Donald J. Trump is considering doing so too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Deregulation and Dishonesty Led to Deadly Grenfell Fire, Inquiry Finds
description: A damning final report into Britain’s worst residential fire since World War II blamed a litany of cost-cutting, dishonest sales practices and lax regulation for the blaze that killed 72 people.
content: Seven years after flames engulfed Grenfell Tower, a public housing block in West London, killing 72 people, a public inquiry on Wednesday blamed unscrupulous manufacturers, a cost-cutting local government and reckless deregulation for the disaster, Britain’s worst residential fire since World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Dispatches From the Courtroom: Linda Deutsch Breaking the News
description: Covering some of America’s most sensational trials, she produced urgent, pithy “ledes” in the best tradition of wire-service reporting. Here’s a sampler.
content: Linda Deutsch, one of the deans of American courtroom reporting, covered criminal trials for The Associated Press for nearly 50 years. She was a master of the concise opening paragraph — known as the lede — and the evocative sentence or two that followed, in the best tradition of wire-service reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Reshuffles its Government
description: Plus, Daniel Dae Kim takes a risk.
content: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, laid out plans for the broadest reshuffling of his cabinet since the war began two years ago. The country’s foreign minister was one of half a dozen senior officials who offered their resignation yesterday, and a new list of minsters is expected today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Glenn Thrush and Steven Lee Myers
title: U.S. Announces Plan to Counter Russian Influence Ahead of 2024 Election
description: American spy agencies have assessed that the Kremlin favors former President Donald J. Trump, seeing him as skeptical of U.S. support for Ukraine.
content: The United States on Wednesday announced a broad effort to push back on Russian influence campaigns in the 2024 election, as it tries to curb the Kremlin’s use of state-run media and fake news sites to sway American voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Shootings on Highway Near Seattle Injure 5 People
description: Washington State Patrol officers arrested a suspect in the string of shootings, which occurred late on Labor Day along a stretch of Interstate 5.
content: A string of seemingly random shootings along Interstate 5 in Washington State on Monday injured at least five people and struck up to seven vehicles, the police said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Chris Cameron
title: Trump Says There Was ‘No Conflict’ at Cemetery, Despite Official Accounts
description: Speaking to Sean Hannity, Donald Trump contradicted his campaign’s prior statements about a confrontation involving his campaign at Arlington National Cemetery last week.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump insisted in a radio interview on Tuesday that “there was no conflict” between members of his campaign team and an official at Arlington National Cemetery, contradicting his campaign’s previous statements about the episode last week and Army officials’ account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Why Trump’s Unity Picks Are Not Very Unifying
description: Trump is betting that the political fringe will help him win.
content: It is a time-honored political strategy for presidential candidates: Win your primary, hold your convention and then pivot to the center as you work to unite a broad coalition of voters around your cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Who the Swing Voters Are
description: We analyze the voters who could decide the election.
content: About 18 percent of American voters have not made up their minds between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump, recent polls suggest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Slowdown Déjà Vu Rattles Global Markets
description: Investors sent technology stocks and other assets tumbling on concerns that the U.S. economy could be headed for a hard landing.
content: September is known as the worst month of the year for stocks, and so far it’s living up to that reputation — especially for Nvidia shareholders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Nelson C.J
title: Hounded From a Beauty Pageant in South Africa, Then Crowned in Nigeria
description: A South African beauty pageant contestant with Nigerian heritage was forced to withdraw from the competition after her participation fueled anti-immigrant sentiments.
content: On only her second visit to Nigeria, Chidimma Adetshina won that country’s Miss Universe beauty pageant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis and Blaine Davis
title: A House That Memorializes a Vanished New York
description: In Lower Manhattan, the former residence of an artist couple remains unchanged years after their deaths.
content: IN OCTOBER 1976, the artists Geoffrey Hendricks and Brian Buczak met at a SoHo loft party. Hendricks, then 45, was associated with the Fluxus movement, a loose affiliation of 1960s conceptual artists, including Joseph Beuys, John Cage and Yoko Ono, who rejected traditional practices like abstract painting in favor of elaborate performances. Five years earlier, he’d co-starred in a notable one: In the summer of 1971, Hendricks and his wife of 10 years, the artist Nye Ffarrabas (then Bici Forbes), who were both gay, staged a piece called “Flux Divorce,” which involved taking a chain saw to their marriage bed and dividing the entryway to their home with barbed wire. (Their young children, Tyche and Bracken, weren’t around for the actual show; they only observed the cleanup afterward.) Buczak, a painter who was 23 years Hendricks’s junior, had recently relocated from Detroit, where he was raised. As luck would have it, Hendricks had been staying in a dilapidated townhouse in Hudson Square, then a manufacturing neighborhood on the west side of Lower Manhattan, which he’d eventually buy from his younger brother Jon, a Fluxus artist and archivist who lived next door. Buczak moved in a few months later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: What a Puppy Kindergarten Revealed About Raising Exceptional Dogs
description: Brian Hare and Vanessa Woods are studying how the canine mind develops and what makes a successful service dog.
content: Most students at the Biological Sciences Building at Duke University are trying to master the finer points of cellular biology, genetics or evolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: As Groups Have Shifted, Has It Become a ‘Normal’ Election?
description: Unusual demographic patterns are fading, but there are still some differences from the 2020 race.
content: Labor Day usually marks the start of the heart of campaign season, but this year it felt like a lull — a brief respite after two tumultuous months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren, Alan Rappeport and Lauren Hirsch
title: Biden Expected to Block U.S. Steel Takeover
description: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is expected to raise national security concerns about selling the iconic steel producer to Japan’s Nippon Steel.
content: President Biden is preparing to soon block an attempt by Japan’s Nippon Steel to buy U.S. Steel on national security grounds, according to three people familiar with the matter, likely sinking a merger that became entangled in election-year politics in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Terminator Zero’ Reinvigorates a Weary Franchise
description: The Netflix anime series channels familiar themes without feeling like a retread.
content: “Terminator 2: Judgment Day” was a megahit in 1991, and every installment of the franchise since has been at least a little disappointing. Until now: The Netflix anime series “Terminator Zero” is a smart take on the lore, channeling familiar themes without feeling like a retread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Casualties from a Russian strike in Ukraine.
content: Russian missiles yesterday struck a military academy and a neighboring hospital in Poltava, about 100 miles from the Russian border, killing more than 50 people, wounding some 200 others and underscoring Moscow’s superior firepower. It was the latest in a string of deadly Russian strikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth and Yinka Elujoba
title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in September
description: This week in Newly Reviewed, Andrew Russeth covers a group show of self-portraits, Gina Beavers’s collaged sculptures and Hannah Villiger’s beguiling photographs.
content: This week in Newly Reviewed, Andrew Russeth covers a group show of self-portraits, Gina Beavers’s collaged sculptures and Hannah Villiger’s beguiling photographs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Trump Buried the Hatchet With Brian Kemp. Will He Dig It Up Again?
description: Donald Trump needs to win Georgia. That probably means he needs to keep a fragile peace with its popular Republican governor, even as election denialism again courses through the state.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has reached an uneasy truce with Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia, setting aside a yearslong grudge over his Republican counterpart’s refusal to help him overturn the state’s 2020 election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers, Tiffany Hsu and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Emerges as a Top Disinformation Threat in U.S. Presidential Race
description: With a flurry of hacks and fake websites, Iran has intensified its efforts to discredit American democracy and possibly tip the race against former President Donald Trump.
content: A website called Savannah Time describes itself as “your trusted source for conservative news and perspectives in the vibrant city of Savannah.” Another site, NioThinker, wants to be “your go-to destination for insightful, progressive news.” The online outlet Westland Sun appears to cater to Muslims in suburban Detroit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Las Vegas Places a Bet on a New Art Museum, With Help From L.A.
description: The city agreed to give land to a museum championed by the casino magnate Elaine Wynn, which will be a partnership with the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
content: Las Vegas has the Neon Museum, the Mob Museum, the Punk Rock Museum and the Pinball Hall of Fame, among others. But it is currently the largest city in the United States without a major art museum, despite several attempts over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: JD Vance’s Conversion to Catholicism
description: Readers discuss an article about how he discovered his faith. Also: The Hamas tunnels; prioritizing child care; accessibility in Paris and Barcelona.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: The Black List Helped Reshape Hollywood. Can It Change Publishing?
description: Almost 20 years after Franklin Leonard created the Black List, which has helped little-known screenwriters break into Hollywood, it is expanding into fiction.
content: For nearly 20 years, Franklin Leonard has made it his mission to help undiscovered writers find an audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and David Guttenfelder
title: Short Notice and Blocked Exits Proved Lethal in Strike in Ukraine
description: When two Russian ballistic missiles struck a military academy in Poltava, debris blocked corridors and exits. Cadets near a bomb shelter survived. Others did not.
content: The Russian missiles that tore into a Ukrainian military academy on Tuesday proved so lethal because cadets had barely two minutes to seek safety in a bomb shelter and because debris from explosions then blocked emergency exits, the academy director said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Harry Styles’s Favorite Designer Returns
description: Also, everything else you need to know about what’s happening this fashion month.
content: Even in the context of end-of-summer, back-to-school Septembers, this September is going to be a doozy. Not just a return to real life, but crammed with attention-demanding events: the U.S. Open finals, the Harris-Trump debate, the Emmys (which have turned into a mini-Oscars, thanks to streaming). How will fashion month, which begins in New York this week before moving on to London, Milan and Paris, ever compete?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: A New ‘Red Hot’ Album Tackles a Hot Topic: Transgender Awareness
description: “Transa,” with 46 tracks due Nov. 22, brings together artists including Sam Smith, Sade, André 3000 and Jayne County.
content: Over a soft piano riff wafts the unmistakable voice of Sade, singing a song to her son. The lyrics she wrote for the piece — her first new track in 14 years, titled “Young Lion” — are steeped in empathy and regret. “Young man, it’s been so heavy for you/You must have felt so alone,” she sings. “I should have known.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Joaquin Phoenix and the Big Question at the ‘Joker: Folie à Deux’ Premiere
description: At the Venice Film Festival with his co-star, Lady Gaga, would the actor answer questions about dropping out of a Todd Haynes movie?
content: Joaquin Phoenix has never been eager to face the press. The 49-year-old actor grants few interviews, speaks with great reluctance about his process, and once walked out on a journalist when asked whether his film “Joker” might inspire copycat violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Big Band Jazz
description: Big bands were built in the 1920s and ’30s to blast young dancers with layers of rhythm, but creative composers seeking a larger canvas have kept the form alive. Hear 12 big selections.
content: “Big band music” isn’t everybody’s first thought when they’re pondering what to punch into Spotify, we’ll grant you that. But if all big bands make you think of is “jazz hands” and flappers and early black-and-white films, let’s take five minutes to change that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump’s Federal Election Case to Go Back Before a No-Nonsense Judge
description: If her record is any guide, Judge Tanya Chutkan will try to keep pretrial proceedings moving along after a lengthy hiatus and the Supreme Court’s decision granting former presidents broad immunity.
content: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan wasted no time last month when the biggest case of her career — the indictment of former President Donald J. Trump on election interference charges — was handed back to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Suhasini Raj
title: Netflix Adds Disclaimer to Indian Show After Anger Over Hijacker Names
description: The series, based on a 1999 plane hijacking, prompted backlash on social media. Critics claimed it wrongly portrayed the Islamist hijackers as Hindus.
content: Netflix expanded a disclaimer for Indian audiences with a fictional series inspired by the 1999 hijacking of a plane by Islamist militants, after social media users and a high-ranking member of India’s ruling party accused it of portraying the hijackers as Hindus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Harris Wins (and Trump and the Republicans Blow It)
description: To understand Harris’s success, you have to think about Marie Kondo and her ruthless minimalism about clutter.
content: It’s Nov. 6, 2024, the morning after Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Earthy Eggplant That Whispers of Summer and Fall
description: Hetty Lui McKinnon has just the recipe for this time of seasonal change.
content: I’ve done my best in these missives this summer to highlight all of the season’s seemingly endless bounty. Corn, tomatoes, watermelon! Zucchini, too! But there has been a glaring omission, I hate to say, and that’s eggplant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Andy Cohen Lists His Light-Filled West Village Duplex for $14 Million
description: The TV host is trading his 3,500-square-foot apartment, painstakingly assembled over nearly 21 years, for a penthouse in the same neighborhood.
content: Andy Cohen, the TV host, author and longtime producer, spent 21 years building his dream West Village home — a fantastical assemblage of four apartments that he turned into a single 3,500-square foot home where light floods nearly every room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko, Benjamin Oreskes and Nicholas Fandos
title: The Secrets of an Unassuming N.Y. Official Accused of Working for China
description: Linda Sun, a former deputy chief of staff to Gov. Kathy Hochul, used her growing influence to push the interests of the Chinese government, U.S. prosecutors say.
content: Months after a low-level aide in the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo returned from a visit to China in 2019, she got a curious inquiry from federal investigators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: An Agonizing Dilemma: When Obesity Prevents a Joint Replacement
description: Many doctors say it is too dangerous to perform the common surgeries on people with high body mass indexes, but patients say they are facing discrimination.
content: The last time Alicia Kline walked unassisted was in January 2021. She is in constant pain from hip arthritis and uses a walker and a wheelchair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya
title: Japan’s Era of ‘Free’ Mortgages Is Coming to an End
description: Homeowners are gearing up to pay more on their loans as the Bank of Japan’s rate increases signal the end of decades of ultralow interest rates.
content: For years, mortgages in Japan have been nearly cost free. Homeowners are now bracing for that to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Trump Says His Son Barron Is Attending N.Y.U.
description: Donald J. Trump had teased his youngest child’s choice of school for months, but on Wednesday, he was photographed on the university’s campus in Manhattan’s Greenwich Village.
content: Barron Trump, the youngest child of former President Donald J. Trump, has enrolled as a freshman at New York University in Manhattan, his father said in an interview that was published on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Daniel Dae Kim Isn’t Afraid to Fail
description: In the new Broadway production of “Yellow Face,” the “Lost” and “Hawaii Five-0” star is taking a risk. “I am aware,” he says, “that people have not usually seen me in this way.”
content: It’s tough to see the resemblance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman and Insiya Syed
title: Two Years After Deadly Floods Hit Pakistan, It’s Happening Again
description: Millions of people still recovering from the devastation of 2022 are bracing for the possibility of losing what they’ve rebuilt.
content: One recent evening, as heavy monsoon rains pounded down, Fauzia and her extended family of 15 huddled under a makeshift tent, its top patched with large plastic sheets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: ensemble
description: This word has appeared in 609 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word ensemble has appeared 609 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 24 in The New York Times Magazine article “The Mysterious, Deep-Dwelling Microbes That Sculpt Our Planet” by Ferris Jabr:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Hamas Releases Hostage Video of Two Slain Israeli Captives
description: Release of the video of Carmel Gat, 40, and Alexander Lobanov, 32, appears designed to inflame divisions in Israel.
content: Hamas on Wednesday released a video of two hostages, recorded before their deaths, whose bodies were among those recovered earlier this week by the Israeli military from a tunnel in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
title: Mexico’s Lower House of Congress Approves President’s Judicial Overhaul
description: The vote was the first step toward shifting the country to a system in which nearly every judge would be elected to office. The bill now moves to the Senate.
content: Legislators in Mexico’s lower house of Congress on Wednesday morning approved a sweeping proposal to redesign the entire judiciary, the first step toward shifting the country to a system in which nearly every judge is elected to office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Jason Henry, Ben Laffin, Rebecca Lieberman and Yiwen Lu
title: How Self-Driving Cars Get Help From Humans Hundreds of Miles Away
description: Zoox, a self-driving car company owned by Amazon, is deploying robot taxis without steering wheels, driver seats or drivers. But like all other self-driving cars, they still need help from humans.
content: Zoox, a self-driving car company owned by Amazon, is deploying robot taxis without steering wheels, driver seats or drivers. But like all other self-driving cars, they still need help from humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Below Deck Mediterranean’ and More
description: I’m the reporting fellow on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve recently heard, seen and watched.
content: I’m the reporting fellow on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve recently heard, seen and watched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Louise Snyder
title: Who Gets to Kill in Self-Defense?
description: Self-defense laws were written for men. This is how they fail women who fight back.
content: Self-defense laws were written for men. This is how they fail women who fight back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: New York Official Is Charged as Chinese Agent
description: Linda Sun, a former aide to Gov. Kathy Hochul, was charged with 10 criminal counts that included visa fraud, money laundering and other crimes.
content: Linda Sun, a former aide to Gov. Kathy Hochul, was charged with 10 criminal counts that included visa fraud, money laundering and other crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso
title: Russia Launches Deadly Missile and Drone Attacks on Ukraine
description: At least seven people were killed in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, a day after a devastating attack on the eastern city of Poltava left dozens of others dead.
content: At least seven people were killed in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, a day after a devastating attack on the eastern city of Poltava left dozens of others dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Pope Francis Kicks Off Asia Tour in Indonesia
description: The 87-year-old will also visit Papua New Guinea, East Timor and Singapore during his 11-day Asia trip to reach faraway Catholics.
content: The 87-year-old will also visit Papua New Guinea, East Timor and Singapore during his 11-day Asia trip to reach faraway Catholics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: Shooting at Georgia High School Leaves Four Dead
description: The police responded to a shooting at Apalachee High School in Winder, Ga. At least nine others were injured.
content: The police responded to a shooting at Apalachee High School in Winder, Ga. At least nine others were injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Italian Coast Guard
title: 21 Reported Missing After Boat Carrying Migrants Capsizes
description: Italian rescuers said that seven Syrian migrants survived a shipwreck about 10 miles from the island of Lampedusa, in the Central Mediterranean. The survivors told officials that 21 fellow travelers, including three minors, had fallen off during the crossing because of rough seas.
content: Italian rescuers said that seven Syrian migrants survived a shipwreck about 10 miles from the island of Lampedusa, in the Central Mediterranean. The survivors told officials that 21 fellow travelers, including three minors, had fallen off during the crossing because of rough seas.
source.name: The New York Times
